Authors: Wayne M Pitt, Jose R Urbez-Torres, Florent P Trouillas
Title:
Dothiorella and Spencermartinsia, new species and records
from grapevines in Australia
Keywords:
Botryosphaeriaceae, grapevine trunk diseases, grapevine
canker, multigene phylogeny, taxonomy, Vitis vinifera.
Abstract:
Dothiorella and Spencermartinsia are two
Botryosphaeriaceous ascomycete genera found on various woody hosts that
bear coelomycetous asexual morphs with two celled conidia that become
brown and one-septate prior to dehiscence from conidiogenous cells.
Based on morphological characters and phylogeny of DNA sequences of the
internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region and part of the translation
elongation factor (TEF) 1α gene, a coelomycete isolated from dead
discarded grapevine (Vitis vinifera L.) canes in Western Australia is
described as new. Spencermartinsia westrale W.M. Pitt, J.R. Úrbez-Torres
& Trouillas sp. nov. is closely related to the generic type,
Spencermartinsia viticola (A.J.L. Phillips and J. Luque) A.J.L.
Phillips, A. Alves & Crous, but is morphologically and
phylogenetically distinct. Two further species, Dothiorella neclivorem
W.M. Pitt & J.R. Úrbez-Torres and Dothiorella vinea-gemmae W.M. Pitt
& J.R. Úrbez-Torres are similarly described here as new, following
re-examination of strains from existing collections. Both species bore
conidia that were brown and one-septate prior to release from
conidiogenous cells and in phylogenetic analyses of DNA sequences of the
ITS and TEF regions, both were found to occupy distinct sub-clades
within the genus, separate from other presently accommodated species.
Spencermartinsia plurivora Abdollahz., Javadi & A.J.L. Phillips, and
a fourth, currently unnamed Dothiorella species, both originating from
grapevines in South Australia are also reported for the first time in
Australia.
